greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle T(n,k) = A000292(n) if k = 1 otherwise (k-1)*(n-k+1)*(n-k+2)/2, read by rows.
comment: The triangle can also be defined by multiplying the triangles A(n,k)=1 and A158823(n,k), that is, this here are the partial column sums of A158823.
link: G. C. Greubel, Rows n = 1..50 of the triangle, flattened
formula: Sum_{k=1..n} T(n, k) = binomial(n+3, 4) = A000332(n+3). - _G. C. Greubel_, Apr 01 2021
example: First few rows of the triangle are:
mathematica: Table[T[n, k], {n, 12}, {k, n}]//Flatten (* _G. C. Greubel_, Apr 01 2021 *)
program: (Magma) A158824:= func< n,k | k eq 1 select Binomial(n+2,3) else (k-1)*Binomial(n-k+2,2) >; [A158824(n, k): k in [1..n], n in [1..12]]; // _G. C. Greubel_, Apr 01 2021
def A158824(n,k): return binomial(n+2,3) if k==1 else (k-1)*binomial(n-k+2,2)
flatten([[A158824(n,k) for k in (1..n)] for n in (1..12)]) # _G. C. Greubel_, Apr 01 2021
results.author: _Gary W. Adamson_ & _Roger L. Bagula_, Mar 28 2009
